qas.question: What are examples of Youth radio stations?

answers.text: ABC Triple J and youth run SYN

qas.question: Which music stations strive to play under represented music?

answers.text: Triple J, and similarly PBS and Triple R

qas.question: Which radio station caters for gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender audiences?
Which station caters to sports fans and enthusiasts?
3MBS and ABC Classic FM play what type of music?

context: A long list of AM and FM radio stations broadcast to greater Melbourne. These include "public" (i.e., state-owned ABC and SBS) and community stations. Many commercial stations are networked-owned: DMG has Nova 100 and Smooth; ARN controls Gold 104.3 and KIIS 101.1; and Southern Cross Austereo runs both Fox and Triple M. Stations from towns in regional Victoria may also be heard (e.g. 93.9 Bay FM, Geelong). Youth alternatives include <a0_0>ABC Triple J and youth run SYN<a0_0/>. <a1_0>Triple J, and similarly PBS and Triple R<a1_0/>, strive to play under represented music. <a2_0>JOY 94.9<a2_0/> caters for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender audiences. For fans of <a4_0>classical<a4_0/> music there are 3MBS and ABC Classic FM. Light FM is a contemporary Christian station. AM stations include ABC: 774, Radio National, and News Radio; also Fairfax affiliates 3AW (talk) and Magic (easy listening). For sport fans and enthusiasts there is <a3_0>SEN 1116<a3_0/>. Melbourne has many community run stations that serve alternative interests, such as 3CR and 3KND (Indigenous). Many suburbs have low powered community run stations serving local audiences.
